reviewText:
It might be a sign that you're getting old, if you watch a recently released movie and keep being reminded of better ones that came out years ago.  Or it could be a sign that the movie itself is not very good.

"Men, Women and Children," seemed to me to have a lot of similarities to "American Beauty."  Both open with the main character (here it's Adam Sandler) masturbating, the implication being that he's lost any satisfaction he once had in his marriage. Both take place in suburbia, and all the characters, regardless of age, appear to be clinically depressed and groping after some kind of alternative.  But while "American Beauty's" characters discovered a kind of warped joy in bending the rules, "Men, Women and Children," which follows a group of middle-class families as they deal with the current online/texting culture, is mostly dull and preachy.  (Spoiler)  Everyone gets their knuckles rapped for misbehaving and ends the movie as down as they began.

The movie opens with a shot of outer space and is narrated by Emma Thompson, who if she weren't kept off-screen would outshine the rest of the cast.  The film might be more exciting if it stayed in the Milky Way, but it quickly moves to suburbia.  Adam Sandler plays a grownup here and gives an admirably subdued performance as the father of a teenage son with a porn addiction.  Sandler and his own wife are dissatisfied with their relationship, and both wind up secretly seeking online diversion.  Jennifer Garner plays a mom who keeps a tighter vigilance over her daughter's online activities than the CIA.  The girl's love interest, played by Ansel Elgort, has just quit the football team, after his mom moved out, and is becoming obsessed by role playing games.  Another teen girl deals with an eating disorder (fueled by yes, the Internet) and whether or not to have sex.  Another character wants to be an actress and has a modeling website, run by her mom, who is one of those "cool" parents.  There are various crises and confrontations.  It is never explained why adults of this generation (I'm assuming it's "X") who presumably grew up with video games and computers would have such extreme reactions to their offspring's' online activities.

I wanted to give this movie a much higher rating, since it did not feature (like the last two movies I saw) a character repeatedly vomiting or being murdered during sex, but there were too many stories going on at once, many of which did not have much of a resolution, and the overall mood throughout was dreary, which is all right if the film also stimulates my brain, but here it did not.

The Internet has changed our lives. This movie explores the many ways it has infiltrated our society, particularly that of teenagers, and their parents' bewildered response. This R-rated (for VERY graphic dialogue) outing is directed by Jason Reitman ("Juno" and "Up in the Air") from a script he co-wrote with Erin Cressida Wilson based on Chad Kultgen's novel by the same name.

It is shocking to my generation to see how "wired" modern life has become, and it is even MORE shocking to peek at someone else's correspondence. We are exposed to snippets of pornography, anorexia, chat rooms, on-line bullying, extramarital adventures and the pain of awkward teenage dating.

Here is a small part of this highly capable cast:
  * Adam Sandler ("Grown Ups") is Don Truby, a father who has his own skill set for on-line contacts. He isn't above looking at his son's computer usage...and then his wife's... Oops!
  * Rosemarie DeWitt ("Kill the Messenger") His wife Helen, is branching out for no good reason except possibly boredom.
  * Jennifer Garner ("Draft Day") Patricia has mastered on-line skills so she can keep track of her daughter's life. There isn't a keystroke or a digital signal that she hasn't compulsively followed. This is a control freak run amok and we pity her poor daughter!
  * Kaitlyn Dever ("Short Term 12") is Brandy; her mother has quickly learned the ropes of on-line networking and the girl has NO privacy.
  * Dennis Haysbert ("Think Like a Man Too") is secretluvur, a chat room identity, who shows up right where he's supposed to.
  * Judy Greer ("Descendents") Donna Clint is developing a new hobby...smile... Problem is, her daughter is underage and she might be breaking the law.
  * Olivia Crocicchia ("Rescue Me") is Hannah Clint, the vain cheerleader who aspires to be on a television reality show.
  * Ansel Elgort ("The Fault in Our Stars") Tim doesn't want to play football this year, which makes him persona non grata at school. He is a fan of Carl Sagan which leads to a big misunderstanding with the school counselor.
  * Emma Thompson ("Saving Mr. Banks") as the narrator. Her job is to try to bridge the outer space/Carl Sagan aspect of this film with the personal trials and tribulations of teenagers and their parents.

I'm running out of space and haven't covered all of the fine performers. Each individual has his or her moment to shine and there isn't a weak performance. Bottom line, these are all good kids and the parents are doing the best they can, it's just very complicated in today's digital world.

This movie is about several different men, women, and children (hence, the name) and their intersecting lives. Basically we follow a few days in the lives of a few different families. Everyone seems to have their own issues or problems that their family or friends may not be aware of.

Technology and social media are definitely very present themes throughout this movie.  One overprotective mother monitors her daughter's every movement online and in real life by checking her daughter's cell phone location, analyzing Facebook messages and texts, and tracking every keystroke. We see one teenager who is practically addicted to online porn, while another is obsessed with an online RPG. Unhappy and bored in their marriage, a couple both use the Internet to search for partners outside of their marriage.

I thought Men, Women & Children was a good movie, but it was at times a bit too risqu for me. It was a bit of a downer, as I left the movie feeling a bit depressed. I really enjoyed some storylines better than others, but felt that there were a bit too many story lines to follow. I felt the movie suffered as a result of the many competing storylines. At the end of the movie, I thought there were some character's plot lines that had been left unresolved and I didn't have as much closure as I would have preferred.

This movie contains a lot of familiar faces, including Adam Sandler, Jennifer Garner, Judy Greer, Ansel Elgort, J.K. Simmons, and Dennis Haysbert (who will always be President David Palmer from 24 to me). I found Adam Sandler's role in this movie to be unexpected but I was very pleasantly surprised by his acting, and he ended up being one of my favorite parts of the movie. However, the characters that stole the show for me were those of two teenagers, Tim Mooney (Elgort), whose mother has abandoned him and his father for a new man and life in California, and Brandy Beltmeyer (Kaitlyn Dever), whose overprotective mother is smothering and suffocating her. I've enjoyed the recent movies I've seen with Elgort and think he has some great talent, and this movie only reinforced those thoughts for me. I've only seen Dever in a small role on Bad Teacher, but I also thought she was great and look forward to seeing her in a bigger role in the future.

Summing it up, I liked the movie, despite the fact that it was a bit of a downer. It did try to tackle a lot of characters and plots, however, which is perhaps what led me to feel like some items were left unresolved. At times I felt like the movie was trying to do too much. 3 stars for me.

"Men, Women & Children" (2014 release; 119 min.) brings the interwoven stories of a Texas community near Austin living in today's social media frenzy, and the correlating emptiness. As the movie opens, the narrator (Emma Thompson) informs us we are seeing the spacecraft Voyager, launched in 1977, reach the outer limits of our solar system, and as it leaves for unchartered territories, Voyager makes one last photograph of earth, a mere "pale blue dot". We are then introduced to the ensemble cast: Helen and Don (played by Rosemary DeWitt and Adam Sandler) are unhappily married and before long, they are having affairs. Patricia (played by Jennifer Garner) has a tight, if not suffocating, control of how her daughter Brandy (played by Kaitlyn Dever) uses her smartphone and computer. Don (plated by) is struggling to adjust to life after his wife left him and their son Tim (played by Ansel Elgort). Meanwhile, Tim, a star football player, has quit the football team, much to the despair of the glory-seeking school admin and also his dad. And on and on. There are at least 5 or 6 other main characters but to tell you might spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: "Men, Women & Children" is directed and co-written by Jason Reitman, he of "Juno", "Thank You for Smoking", and "Up In the Air", just to name those. Even though the story line is very different from "Up In the Air", there certainly are parallels in the themes: loneliness, despair, and the need for kindness. While the adults certainly fall short on many levels, I couldn't help but feel for the high school kids, assuming that what is portrayed in the film bears resemblance to reality. It's all about the "hook-up" culture, and status. And why would you talk when you can text the person standing 5 ft. away from you? Given the all-star ensemble cast, there are many choice performances, including Jennifer Garner as the unlikeable and suffocating mom, but I also liked Judy Greer's performance (as another one of the moms). Also note that there is a delightful soundtrack for this movie, with among others a fantastic cover of Donna Summer's "I Feel Love", dramatically slowed down by Nick Hallett and Ray Sweeten. The movie's last 15-20 minutes are fantastic, and when Emma Thompson's voice-over concludes the movie with reading from Carl Sagan's "Pale Blue Dot" book as we see Voyager continue on its never-ending journey, it feels just right.

"Men, Women & Children" has not gotten good reviews, generally speaking, The movie opened on a couple of screens this weekend here in Cincinnati, and I went to see it with low expectations. Because of the large cast, it took me a while to familiarize myself with all of the characters, but once that was done, I thought the movie was far better than what I had been led to believe. The matinee screening where I saw this at today was poorly attended, but this does not surprise me as this is not a 'feel good' movie like "Juno" or in a way even "Up In the Air" was. If you have a chance to see "Men, Women & Children", be it in the theater or on DVD/Blu-ray, I'd suggest you check this out and draw your own conclusion.

The older I get (I'm 40) and the more I experience of life's highs and lows (more low than high lately), the more I gravitate to these type of quirky, offbeat, indie "dramedies".  The stories and characters just feel more real, human, and relateable than most Hollywood stuff.  Right up my alley.  Its like they opened up a new world to me and made me realize its ok to just be myself, not some "normal", soulless, successful, macho, "alpha male" cliche.  Highly flawed but basically good hearted people just trying to do their best, in their own messed up way, to make sense of and survive this Type A, capitalist, Trump-loving society and scary world of "normal" people and "grown-ups" ::shudder::.  Sign me up.  My kind of people.

Related to a lot of these characters, but probably mostly to Ansel's (despite him being much younger than me, haha) due to his "doomed relationship".  Anyway, not a perfect movie and certainly not for everyone, so I can kinda understand the low ratings (I give it a 4 out of 5), and I like director Jason Reitman's film Up in the Air better (my fave by him), and I'm not sure I agree with some reviews saying social media is separating us from each other (can be a great way for shy, awkward, introverted, etc people to connect), but this may be his most human film.  Definitely about people longing and searching for connection and as I said that's right up my alley.  So this is the one I decided to review :)

Anyway, so if anyone out there (of all ages) has ever felt different from the herd, ever felt lost, alienated, or like they don't belong in this world, I'd definitely recommend this movie to you, my fellow misfit and kindred spirit :)  If you agree with my review at all, you can mostly find me these days at twitter dot com/ShyLivesMatter Peace :)

As an ensemble film, we are told many different stories that happen at the same time, but they all revolve around society's changing with today's internet. It shows us just how less interested we have become of most reality, and how we're constantly dependent on our phones and tablets. The film dives into the themes of loneliness, depression, isolation, puberty, profanity, shame, adultery, over-protective restriction, and even suicide. These themes are perfectly represented in almost all of these stories, and every single one of the cast members do a fantastic job of portraying them.

If I had to choose one story that stuck out with me the most, it would have to be the romance between Kaitlyn Dever and Ansel Elgort. What really cements it in, is that they are parallels of one another, as they both have mothers who never understood them, and they have their own online worlds they exist in to get away from all the crap that is surrounding their lives. And when their worlds are taken from them, they either find true happiness within each other, or feel like there's no where else to turn. The ending of this left me in tears, as it was just one heartbreaking moment after the next. As someone who has been suffering from depression and feeling suicidal, I relate a lot to this. I know how it feels to be treated unfairly or told that your longtime passions or hobbies aren't what others want. To me, this is the role that I think truly defines Elgort's talents as an actor.

As for any runner ups tales, it would have to be with Elena Kampouris and Will Peltz, giving us a depiction on how far people will go just to get noticed or not made a complete joke out of, and what the consequences will be when going too far. While not much can be said about Will Peltz, the main highlight here is Elena Kampouris. I feel like this film should be shown to all those girls forcefully starving themselves. You know what I mean, those girls who think they're fat but they really aren't.

I have to also give props to the story involving Adam Sandler and Rosemarie DeWitt. Not only does this showcase lost desires, years after marriage, but it also turns cliches on their sides, in ways you don't expect them to. And DeWitt and Sandler both give excellent performances to back it all up. I still hold the fact that I'm an Adam Sandler fan, but I do agree with people that he does manage to do better with dramatic work.

Men, Women, and Children is a film I'm glad I got to see. Performances aside, the writing and direction are flawless, and Jason Reitman has truly cemented himself as one of the best working director's in Hollywood. And as far as I'm concerned, this is his best film.

To be clear, I rated this as five stars, not because I loved it or even liked it.  Reitman's film is a commentary on the breathtaking change in relationships, every variety and on all levels since the dawn of our urgent need for constant  and instant connection via wifi and our device of choice.  As a mom of two daughters, it was difficult to watch, My girls are 12 years apart.  Same dad, same hometown, my firstborn and her younger sister , however, could not have different experiences, largely due to this new normal: our obsession with tech.  The film underscores how Carl Sagan has achieved the desired effect.  The supposition of Sagan's flimsy pseudo science theory of the "Pale Blue Dot" has done what no dictator or grassroots political movement could.  This film couples Sagan's belief in humanity's lack of uniqueness, purpose or reason for existence with the dividing of life before and after 9/11.  It was this new day of infamy, 9/11 which traumatized the nation in ways we are still learning. Teens, married couples, everyone trying to connect (and remain so) have been hugely effected and blind-sided by the implications of our brave new world, in which we gladly hand over our cash and our privacy to have our phones on us or our computers in front of us at all times.  We know the dangers, the freedoms we are gambling away, but we do it anyway... But more valuable than our money or freedom is the loss of relationships with each other, with our children.  It is all uncharted territory, and we are making a mess of it.  The movie reviewing professionals have dissed and dismissed this film for poor writing, and the usual movie-making flaws.  Writing this, as a mother who held my newborn daughter as I watched the twin towers fall in realtime, I can say that this film does indeed capture the momentous change we have witnessed and experienced together in the years that have followed since that awful day.  As for keeping us safer or facilitating deeper connection, this new form of communicating has served to deliver the opposite:  we are further distanced into our own worlds.  For teens, trying to understand themselves, each other and navigating basic relationships, texting has taught them to dispense with conventional face to face contact.  The mood of the film is insecure, dark and pretty hopeless.  Sadly, I believe the film captured the activities and actual mood of American society quite accurately.  We need a wake up call.

In a world of avoided uncomfortable truths, this movie takes a dive into the deep intricacies of modern, human relations. A film that could have been derailed by aiming at stereotypes, this journey is one of familiarity... either by way of personal experience or experience not too far removed from one's own pillow.

For two hours, I found myself on a journey that was terribly horrific to watch, but refreshingly honest. I was torn constantly between the desire to turn off the movie and the need to continue forth. I also spent a great deal of the last act questioning whether the damage of our technological age can be reversed without following in the footsteps of Garner's wonderfully portrayed and well-meaning character.

There was no part of this movie that wasn't well done.  The writing, the acting, the cinematography... all amazing. Unfortunately, it all works together to create a gut-wrenching film that conveys a much needed message in our generation.  It's the overwhelming honesty of this film that kept it from commercial success. Yet, the reality is that this film could change the lives of those that endure the journey. I would challenge anyone of mature and intelligent thinking to brave the viewing of this film.

Fair warning:  this film contains a plethora of adult themes, content, and language (cursing and otherwise).  This material has been handled with the highest degree of care, integrity, and gentleness, affordable to a film of such brutal realism. Please do not watch around children and avoid at all costs if you are easily nonplussed by adult or sexual material.

I don't understand why this movie is at 31% on Rotten Tomatoes.  I can only assume it's because the critics approached it as being some kind of scathing critique of web technology and thus found it superficial, but I really don't think that's what this movie is trying to do.  It's simply an interweaving contemporary melodrama with a heavy technology element--and a really well done one at that.  The performances are believable and honest, the writing is full of memorable one-liners and scenes, and the production values are top notch.  The central romance between Kaitlyn Dever and Ansel Elgort is way more romantic than any John Green novel adaptation.

My only criticism would be that because the movie has to move so quickly through so many interweaving storylines, nuance is often the first thing to go.  For example, Jennifer Garner's character is and remains ridiculously uptight for the entire movie up until the last scene.  I wanted to know more about why she is the way she is, but because the packed storyline doesn't really allow for for much exploration, we never really know, and thus her final reversal seems rather arbitrary.  The other storylines suffer similarly, but this is a minor critique.  With so many movies coming out that rely so heavily on nostalgia--reboots, remakes, etc--it's so refreshing to see a movie that embraces newness and at least attempts to engage the contemporary world.  That takes guts these days in this risk-averse environment, so I'll add an extra star to my four star review for guts!

I do not watch interpersonal relationship dramas as a rule. We treat others poorly enough as it is without intentionally watching films that give us pointers on new and creative ways to betray our loved one's trust.
That said, I did like this film. I know what you're thinking: "She must have a head injury if she's enjoying Adam Sandler as the dramatic lead."
And that is a legitimate concern. To the best of my knowledge, my grey matter is quite intact.
The film addresses the  complicated network of relationships that an American (or any human) has to navigate on any given day. This is the core plot of most dramatic films. Men, Women and Children fully incorporates the ever-increasing technological complexities that have become an integral part of everyday life. What is your teenager texting on their phone and to whom, or browsing on the Internet? Or your husband, wife, or lover?
This technology can distance us from one another, or bring us closer together. Ultimately, we must control the extent to which it affects our lives.
The acting is decent, although some of the characters (Jennifer Garner's, through no fault of her own) are written a bit two-dimensionally.
And that will teach Amazon to think twice before asking me to review a film again!

This film is all about how solitary we are in such a connected world. The acting was pretty good. The biggest thing you should walk away from this film with is the understanding that we are just a small speck in the universe. The reality is that the more connected we become, the further from each other we are. Stop thinking that a text is the same as a handwritten or spoken word. The world around us is there to enjoy. Reconnect with the ones you love and put down the phone, tablet, or laptop. Humans were made to interact in reality, not virtual reality. Right after I write this review, I'm taking a hike with my daughter, and while my phone will be with me in case of emergency, it will be off so we can enjoy the real world. Maybe we will catch some bugs or collect some leaves, but whatever we do, it will mean something since with did it together.

A powerful look at the alienation of generations, due to our fascination with virtual realities, whether those of technology or the simple inability to look inward and discover our true selves,  let go of our fantasies, forgive and love ourselves. The hope is that at some point we will be able to love ourselves and then, each other.

Possible spoilers.  This well-cast film by Jason Reitman tells the story of how the internet and social media in particular, has changed the routines of millions of Americans.  The large cast depict individual stories in a Texas suburb (shot in Austin) that loosely have a connection.  Adam Sandler, in a rare straight dramatic role (he's fine if constantly sour-faced) plays Don, whose marriage to Helen (Rosemarie DeWitt) has devolved to the point where sex is a scheduled appointment.  He makes up for it with on-line porn.  In an early scene, his computer is so full of pop-up ads and other malware, it won't even function.  So he goes into his 15 year old son Chris's (Travis Tope) room to use his computer and finds that the boy has an even better selection of porn sites.  While this satisfies both males at the time, it causes problems later in the film, especially for Chris.

Judy Greer plays Donna, a single mom who is promoting her teen daughter, Hannah (Olivia Crocicchia) who is in line to get a small acting role in a movie.  She set up a web site for the hopeful model/actress and posted several suggestive photos.  No nudity but risqu, none the less.  Kent Mooney (Dean Norris) and his teen son, Tim (Ansel Elgort) are dealing with their wife and mother abandoning them for another man who lives in California.  She has essentially cut ties with both.  Tim, a star on the football team quits to focus on his on-line video games.  Finally, there is the Beltmeyers (Jennifer Garner, Jason Douglas and Kaitlyn Dever).  Patricia (Garner) is one of those moms who monitors everything on Brandy's (Dever) phone and computer.  It is, in fact, her full time job!  She has an assortment of software and tracking devices she uses to determine Brandy's whereabouts, what she's doing and who she's talking to.  She's even made it known to Brandy as to what she's doing.  Protecting her daughter of course.

It is clear that we are seeing some extremes as to the use of social media.  One mother encourages the use, even posting pictures of her daughter in her underwear.  Another restricts use tighter than North Korea.  A boy gives up active sports for virtual games.  Another boy when faced with his first real sexual encounter, can't get it up.  And then there are the Truby's whose sexual troubles are so great they seek trysts through the web.  Does it all work?  Well, sometimes.

The best scenes are between Tim and Brandy who meet cute in the school cafeteria.  Both Elgort and Devers (so good on TV's "Justified") are promising actors and convey the angst of teens coming of age with emotion and conviction.  The film is hardly uplifting and at times confounding and the connection between the families appears a bit of a stretch.  There is also a confusing overriding theme regarding Earth's place in the Universe.  Narration by Emma Thompson pops up once and a while, as well as a reading in class that makes reference to Carl Sagan's book and the photo from space called Pale Blue Dot.  We see the NASA photo and a simulation of Voyager 1 flying through space at the beginning and end of the film.  This isn't a great movie, but I did think it had relevance in our modern world.

The Blu ray transfer features 1080p encoding and a 1.78:1 aspect ratio.  It is well done as are most major Blu ray features these days.  Colors are excellent, black levels are fine and detail is well defined.  I could see no artifacts or problems whatsoever.  A first rate transfer.  Audio includes a DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 option.  The content of the film isn't demanding and is mostly dialog.  So what I'm looking for is primarily a clear delivery, usually through the center channel.  The disc delivers.  A few scenes include some ambient sounds from the rear but that's about it.  There are English SDH, Spanish, Portuguese and French subtitles.  Extras include some deleted scenes and a couple featurettes (Virtual Intimacy: 13:29 and Seamless Interface: 8:29).

I watch many films (both mainstream and independent) as an avid Netflix viewer, and fine art student in film courses, so it takes a lot for a film to truly speak to me (as snotty as that may sound.) The only thing that I think actually took away from the film was that it was almost 'too pretty'. They say cinematography can either add to, or hinder a film (even when it is super technically sound and aesthetically pleasing) but i think that the matter that this film dealt with was too real and gritty to have a perfect, glazed over visuals. You also really need to be careful not to glamourize things like eating disorders. I'm not sure.. I could be wrong.. but coming from a female artist's point of view, that's all I have to say about that. Overall, I was really glad to see actors taken out of their typical type cast roles (mainly the adult comedy actors) and do a fantastic job and not give a hint of goofiness, but rather, play a very convincing average, middle class modern day American in any old town. And the fact that the younger actors were given a chance to show their abilities was very valuable as well.

This is a thoughtful movie focused on the question: What is the cost of living online?

Characters IM, txt, game, and surf their way through life in this movie that is simultaneously about kids, adult relationships, families, and what could be called regular stressors. Each character in this film is thrown for a loop in one way or another, and yet they (largely) recover. There's some true love, true betrayal, and everything in between.

For Adam Sandler fans, it's cool to see him playing a serious character in this one -- and doing it so well. Many other great actors are in this movie, including Dean Norris who plays Hank (Hank!) in Breaking Bad. Good old Hank does a great job here.

While the feel-better ending of this film seemed like an easy out for me, the movie really got me thinking.

While it's far from perfect, this movie is a deeply thought-provoking and disturbing movie.  It addresses real issues we all face because of the Internet's integration into our lives.  But it never blames the Internet for anything.  It demonstrates humanity's tendencies THROUGH its use and abuse of the Internet.  Fascinating and sad.  Creepy and liberating.  We live, love, destroy, abuse, and explore on the Internet.

Pornography, cheating, bullying, gaming, friendships, learning, absorbing other philosophies via Youtube, posting too much, posting too little, posting as others, using the Internet to display a different side of yourself--it's all here in graphic detail.  All the effects of using the Internet, misunderstanding the Internet, and fearing the Internet.

Slowly paced, but never boring.  You will see quite a few real-life situations, tragedies, etc. mirrored in this movie.

With perfect performances and tight writing that draw you in before you realize what's happening; Men, Women, & Children will have an impact on you.  Like all good art.

WATCH IT.  You'll probably not want to relive it, so don't buy it.  Yet it is a poignant commentary on humanity at this very time in our history.

Alright, this movie is a bit of a mess, with way too many characters and storylines, and some uncertainty about whether it wants to be a witty drama or a campy "dramady."  It aspires to be the American Beauty (1999) of our age, giving us a poignant and profound snapshot of middle class white Americana the way that movie did at the turn of the millennium.  Unfortunately it comes up way short.  That director Jason Reitman had this earlier film in mind is evident from the comment he left on the Amazon page for the book by the same title on which this movie is based (an extremely graphic sexual work which makes this movie appear tame by comparison) in which he compared the book to American Beauty and The Graduate.  The main problem is too many characters.  Cheerleader Hannah Clint is a wannabe Hollywood starlet who seems too pre-fabricated (as portrayed by Olivia Crocicchia) to be believable as a stage mom's teen daughter.  Another anorectic cheerleader character could also be eliminated.  And so on.  Books don't translate well into movies unless you streamline the storyline and jettison the non-essential characters.  Perhaps Robert Altman could juggle 24 characters in his movie Nashville (1975), but success with this style of film is the exception to the rule and such complicated scripts are usually just too problematic.

That being said this the movie has some surprisingly good performances by Adam Sandler, Dean Norris, and Ansel Elgort, and a very disappointing one by Jennifer Garner.  Garner's character is so extreme it would have been better suited to a broad comedy, and no actress has been so poorly served by a director since Faye Dunaway in Mommie Dearest.  It is the director's job to not let actors embarrass themselves but Reitman clearly failed Garner here.

The movie is nicely filmed and scored, and quite beautiful and haunting in parts, not unlike American Beauty. It's just inundated by so many extraneous characters, overly obvious and somewhat dated messages, and it's own desire to be profound (five separate references to Carl Sagan's Pale Blue Dot - twice by one of the characters and three times by the narrator - just so we don't miss it) that the few good performances and poignant themes get obscured in the clutter.  This movie could have been less preachy about online addictions and the anonymity that breeds cruelty and instead focus in on it's more subtle theme of alienation and emptiness in the digital age.  The one ideal relationship in the movie is between two of the teens, Brandy and Tim, played by Kaitlyn Dever and Ansel Elgort, who establish their bond based on human contact and affection  (two things you can't get from a website, app, or online game).

I give this ambitious film three stars for what it gets right, but it's nowhere near the film it aspires to be.

I can't remember the last time I enjoyed a performance from Adam Sandler. That is, aside from his role in "Punch-Drunk Love" a full twelve years ago. He's an actor that's always had a certain potential that seemed to be wasted on the pointless, raunchy comedies he's churned out for the past few decades.

But, hopefully his emotional performance in "Men, Women & Children" serves as a precursor to more interesting work to come. Despite its flaws, this is one of the most timely and deeply affecting pieces of work I've seen in a long time.

It's a movie that tries to tackle many subjects, all under the bubble of technology. At the forefront, we see Sandler's character struggling with his marriage and trying to work out some of his various problems. There's also several other intertwining stories, some that deal with infidelity and young love, and others that handle issues with self-image and peer pressure. They're not all equal in quality (that being expected), but each one certainly has something to say.

The most well-developed segment includes Ansel Elgort (who you may know from "The Fault in Our Stars"), playing a teen struggling with having just quit his high-school football team. We see him concerned over the meaning of life and this is only alleviated as he gets to know a girl named Brandy. Their relationship in the film is beautiful - and so is most of the movie - with a few exceptions here and there. It's a film that starts off a bit rocky and doesn't really find its footing until the first thirty minutes have past. But once it does, it proves to be shockingly true and current. These are issues that people are dealing with on a daily basis, and it handles them in a touching and true manner that can't be rivaled by the majority of mainstream movies out today.

To say anything negative about this movie due to it's cast or it's predecessors is a wasteful shame.  No parent can hear these same messages too many times, too many ways, or by too many A - Z list actors.  If there are children in your life that you love, pay the $4 and get the messages this film was intended to give.  It's not a blockbuster, a grammy winner, or even likely to make it in any one person's top 100 all time favorite movie lists - it's a portrait of extremes meant to blatantly remind of you how increasingly complicated life becomes with forever evolving technology taking center stage.

Men, Women & Children, the sixth feature by writer and director Jason Reitman (Juno, Up in the Air), does not deserve the severe critical lambasting it has received.  Set in a Texas suburb, the film depicts how various people's lives, loves, and day-to-day experiences are facilitated, shaped, or stunted by the Internet and the technology in their lives.  Or, put another way, it is an Internet-age reflection on such enduring concerns and rites as coming-of-age, infidelity, and parental responsibility.  Rosemarie DeWitt and Adam Sandler portray a bored couple both considering extramarital experimentation.  Judy Greer is a mother who tried and failed to become a star in California and now condones and encourages her teenage daughter's oversexed exhibitionism and voracious desire for fame.  Jennifer Garner co-stars as another mother, one almost driven mad by her fixation with monitoring and policing her put-upon daughter's computer and phone.  Other stories touch on pornography, high-school peer pressure manifested online, and the way people, enabled by their digital devices, can be alone together.

Now and then, I admit, Reitman reaches an inch too far or lapses into modestly ponderous pretense.  For example, the slice-of-life Texas stories are blended with shots of the Voyager 1 spacecraft floating in interstellar space in a too-cute bid to contrast relatively microscopic human experiences with the ambivalent grandeur of the cosmos, and the sheer volume of tech-centric conversations and crises threatens to resemble a wag of the self-righteous finger a few times.  Yet there is so much of enormous quality here, from moments of genuine insight (and painful recognition) to a veritable catalog of strong performances, including by the very natural teenage actors.  The various poignant subplots, a few laced with relaxed humor, drew me in.  This is perhaps the highest compliment I can pay this unduly maligned picture:  it is involving and satisfying.

Whats it about?

In modern-day Texas, three compromised families are fraught with lust, change and despair as they navigate the world found online and off.

What did I think?

In this soothingly intimate and captivating film, Reitman (the director of Juno and Up in the Air) pulls together various stories in a sincere bid to understand how technology is infused into our lives, by visually representing the characters text messages and computer desktops with great flair. His broad approach can sometimes become disaffecting, particularly with a motif involving an intergalactic satellite and narration by Emma Thompson, but his amazing cast of actors (which includes the likes of Adam Sandler, Jennifer Garner and Judy Greer) give highly engaging and nuanced performances. Its unabashedly dramatic, but also quite humorous and much more self-aware than many reviewers give it credit for.

Jason Reitman has been responsible for some of the best portraits of modern life in America, made in the past ten years or so. His fearless character studies have tackled narcissism (Thank You for Smoking,) teen pregnancy (Juno,) crippling loneliness (Up in the Air,) and mental illness/alcoholism (Young Adult.) Men, Women & Children is Reitmans attempt at a modern-day remake of Ordinary People, rewritten for todays generation.

I almost skipped on this film in my local theaters too-short one week engagement of it, because critical reviews have panned it, which I certainly wasn't expecting, given Reitmans track record of timely and well-developed films. This is a time where I really think everybody missed the point. It wants to be an important film about how social media is dehumanizing us, and it succeeded, at least to me.

The film follows several semi-interconnected stories and characters and their sad, inconsequential little lives. They include a couple mutually uninterested in their own marriage, each leading separate affairs (Rosemarie DeWitt and Adam Sandler,) their porn-addicted son (Travis Tope,) a mother (Jennifer Garner) who tyrannically monitors every movement her outcast daughter (Kaitlyn Dever) makes, who falls hard for a similar outcast (Ansel Elgort) who is disgusted with his home life. A progressive parent (Judy Greer) created a website for her daughter, an aspiring actress (Olivia Crocicchia,) when she may be doing her daughter more harm than good. Domestic violence, eating disorders, teen suicide, mental and physical abuse, class struggle and social alienation are some of this films many conversation-starting themes.

So I was very worried about Adam Sandler in a legit movie. I tend to forget hes shown us he can do dramatic work, as evidenced in Punch Drunk Love. He gives a nuanced and very fine performance here, and doesnt detract at all from everything else going on. Ansel Elgort, of The Fault in Our Stars also does very nice work. Really, though, there isn't a bad performance across the board, which is saying a lot, considering this is a film of many younger up-and-comers.

A credit sequence that shows The Voyager Space Probe moving past planet after planet, emphasizing how unimportant Earth, and therefore all of us, are on a grand scale, but the film shows us that even though its become nearly impossible, one can make a human connection in a world that has become desensitized by technology.

And yes, Reitman is a little too heavy-handed with the films themes, a lot of them appearing more obvious than they should. And, yes, Men, Women & Children may not be telling us anything that we don't already know about the world, but you're likely to find more than one or two characters here who you will relate to. This is a film that desperately wants its viewer to lead a more meaningful life. Its a film that, with a few minor tweaks, could have been an Oscar contender, and would have been seen widely, as it should, rather than by a limited audience. Its a real downer, in truth, but it should inspire thought about how little you know about yourself and everyone around you.

Grade: A-
